thread.title: Humana latest insurer to exit Obamacare exchanges
thread.title_full: Humana latest insurer to exit Obamacare exchanges

author: Tom Howell Jr.
title: Humana latest insurer to exit Obamacare exchanges
text:
More... Sami Jamaleddine, left, signs up for health insurance offered under the Affordable Care Act with insurance agent Michael Khoury, right, Tuesday, Jan. 31, 2017, in Miami. The enrollment period for the federal health care law known as “Obamacare” ends at ... more >   Tom Howell Jr.   Updated: 8:00 p.m. on Tuesday, February 14, 2017 
Humana, one of the country’s largest insurers, said Tuesday it plans to drop out of the Obamacare exchanges after this year — a development that caused both sides of the health reform debate, including President Trump himself, to quickly point fingers. 
The company said it tried everything it could to make money off its individual-market plans, most of which are offered through the Affordable Care Act’s web exchanges, but early returns from this year’s sign-up period weren’t promising. 
“Therefore, the company has decided that it cannot continue to offer this coverage for 2018,” the company said. 
Other major insurers, including UnitedHealth Group and Aetna, caused a firestorm by dropping out of Obamacare markets after earlier rounds. They said the exchanges weren’t profitable, after the law’s “individual mandate” requiring people to hold insurance failed to prod enough young and healthy customers into the market place. 
Instead, they faced a rash of sicker customers with costly medical claims, forcing them to hike their rates or exit the program. 
Mr. Trump said the Humana decision proves that “Obamacare continues to fail.” 
“Humana to pull out in 2018. Will repeal, replace & save healthcare for ALL Americans,” Mr. Trump said. 
Republicans who control all levers of government say they’re working on a plan to replace Obamacare’s heavy mandates with market reforms that will entice people into plans. 
They haven’t fully sketched out a plan for scrapping the law and ensuring a smooth transition, however, leading some analysts to fear that uncertainty will cause more insurers to flee the program. 
Democrats said the GOP’s murky plans are already “sabotaging” the law. 
“Republicans’ refusal to provide certainty is harming American business and middle-class consumers,” said Rep. Richard Neal, Massachusetts Democrats and top-ranking Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee. “Republicans complain there is lack of choice, but it is their policies that are causing competition to wither.” 
Mr. Trump yanked up to $5 million in advertising for HealthCare.gov, the federal Obamacare website, during the critical final week of 2017 signups last month. 
Ultimately, the number of people selecting plans on the website dropped 4 percent this go-around compared to the 2016 season. 
Democrats immediately blamed Mr. Trump, saying signups had been running ahead of schedule while Mr. Obama was overseeing things, but enthusiasm appeared to wane in the final days after Mr. Trump took over. 
They say the GOP should fix the law instead with more generous subsidies or a government-run “public option” to compete with private plans.
